title: Understanding and Applying Mathematical Concepts
driving_question: How can we apply mathematical concepts and procedures to solve real-world problems?
short_background_context: The New York State Education Department administers Mathematics Tests every year and releases a significant portion of the questions for review and use. These questions are designed to assess the New York State P–12 Next Generation Learning Standards for Mathematics, which include both grade-level standards and the “Standards for Mathematical Practices”. The questions are often framed within the context of real-world applications and require students to complete multiple steps, drawing on the simultaneous application of multiple skills and concepts.
tasks: Analyze a set of multiple-choice questions from the Mathematics Tests and identify the mathematical concepts and procedures being assessed.
Choose one of the constructed-response questions and solve it, showing all your work. Explain the steps you took and why.
Create your own two-credit constructed-response question that requires the application of multiple mathematical skills and real-world applications.
pre_thinking_prompts: What mathematical concepts and procedures do you think will be most commonly assessed in these questions?
How might real-world applications be incorporated into these questions?
What strategies can you use to solve multi-step problems?
reflection_prompt: What have you learned about applying mathematical concepts and procedures to solve problems? How did creating your own question help deepen your understanding?
ai_tutor_prompts: Can you explain why you chose those steps to solve the problem?
How does this mathematical concept apply to real-world situations?
What other strategies could you have used to solve this problem?
remix_zone: Students could remix this problem by creating a three-credit constructed-response question that requires the application of multiple mathematical skills and real-world applications. They could also create a multiple-choice question that assesses a specific mathematical concept or procedure.
